results.abstract: S Amer pistol champion D Guimaraes is wounded in neck when he exchanges gunfire with burglar who entered his home; will not compete in scheduled Mex shooting tournament

headline.main: Astronaut in Hospital; Notes on People

results.snippet: James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, was at the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after suffering chest pains while playing handball.
results.lead_paragraph: James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, was at the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after suffering chest pains while playing handball.

results.abstract: veteran Soviet astronaut Maj Gen V A Shatalov says on Apr 10 that Salyut space station, launched over wk ago by USSR, might not be occupied by astronauts for a while

headline.main: TROUBLE IS HINTED ON SALYUT FLIGHT; U.S. Experts Ponder Soviet Delay in Sending Up Crew 'Put on the Shelf' Delay in Manned Mission Soviet Astronaut Comments

results.snippet: It has been more than a week since the Soviet Union launched its Salyut 2 space station, and American observers are now wondering why astronauts have riot been sent out to occupy it - wondering if some serious trouble has developed.
results.lead_paragraph: It has been more than a week since the Soviet Union launched its Salyut 2 space station, and American observers are now wondering why astronauts have riot been sent out to occupy it - wondering if some serious trouble has developed.

results.abstract: Ed notes new series of 'horror stories' revealed by recent NYC HR hearing on condition of US mail service; examples of delayed deliveries cited; says Postal Service has reduced amount of Govt subsidy it requires at expense of patron, who now pays much higher postage for much poorer service
results.snippet: The first in a nationwide series of Congressional hearings has added a thick new layer of horror stories to those that-have been piling up for months about the condition of the United States mails-a condition charitably described by one Congressman...
results.lead_paragraph: The first in a nationwide series of Congressional hearings has added a thick new layer of horror stories to those that-have been piling up for months about the condition of the United States mails-a condition charitably described by one Congressman as "a national disgrace."

results.abstract: USSR on Apr 18 denies repts that it plans to launch manned space vehicle to link up with orbiting Salyut 2 space station

headline.main: SOVIET DENIES PLAN FOR MANNED FLIGHT

results.snippet: The Soviet Union has no plans to launch a manned space vehicle to link up with the orbiting station Salyut 2, space sources said today. The Salyut station was launched April 3, but the Soviet authorities did not disclose details of its mission.
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union has no plans to launch a manned space vehicle to link up with the orbiting station Salyut 2, space sources said today. The Salyut station was launched April 3, but the Soviet authorities did not disclose details of its mission.

results.abstract: US space officials strongly suspect that a 'catastrophic failure' connected with USSR's orbiting Salyut space station has prevented astronauts from boarding it; repts from well-informed sources indicate that critical failure occurred more than wk ago, and is thought to associated with unusually large number of fragments that have been tracked near spacecraft; repts indicate that radio signals from Salyut have ceased and that craft is tumbling out of control

headline.main: U.S. Space Observers Suspect 'Catastrophic Failure' of Salyut

results.snippet: American space experts strongly suspect that a "catastrophic failure" connected with the Soviet Union's Salyut 2 prevented Soviet astronauts from making an attempt to man the large, earth-orbiting space station.
results.lead_paragraph: American space experts strongly suspect that a "catastrophic failure" connected with the Soviet Union's Salyut 2 prevented Soviet astronauts from making an attempt to man the large, earth-orbiting space station.

results.abstract: Nazi leader R Hess Apr 26 celebrates his 75th birthday at Spandau Prison in West Berlin; is described as being in relatively good health

keywords.value: NUREMBERG TRIAL OF LEADING GERMAN WAR CRIMINALS (OCT '45-OCT '46)

results.snippet: James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, left the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after three weeks of treatment for the heart attack he suffered while playing handball on April 4.
results.lead_paragraph: James B. Irwin, the retired astronaut, left the Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center in Aurora, Colo., after three weeks of treatment for the heart attack he suffered while playing handball on April 4.

results.abstract: USSR on Apr 28 concedes serious setback in its manned space program by announcing end of flight of orbiting Salyut space station, which had been tumbling in uncontrolled fashion through space since launching on Apr 3 after unspecified accident evidently caused heavy damage to vehicle; says flight yielded 'important experimental data confirming the correctness of the adopted engineering designs and of the specifications of basic systems and apparatus aboard the station'; Soviet astronaut Popovich illus with former US astronaut Col Borman in Moscow

headline.main: Soviet Is Set Back as Salyut Flight Ends; New Vehicles Planned

results.snippet: The Soviet Union announced today the end of the flight of its orbital workshop Salyut 2, in effect conceding a serious setback to its manned space program.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union announced today the end of the flight of its orbital workshop Salyut 2, in effect conceding a serious setback to its manned space program.

results.abstract: USSR on Apr 28 names newly-discovered mineral Armstrongite, after former US astronaut N A Armstrong, 1st human to set foot on moon
results.snippet: As evidence of the growing goodwill of the Soviet Union toward the United States, Russian scientists have named a newly discovered mineral Armstrongite, after the American astronaut Neil A. Armstrong, Tass reported today.
results.lead_paragraph: As evidence of the growing goodwill of the Soviet Union toward the United States, Russian scientists have named a newly discovered mineral Armstrongite, after the American astronaut Neil A. Armstrong, Tass reported today.
